skill.name: understanding-db-schema
skill.description: Deep expertise in Logseq's Datascript database schema. Auto-invokes when users ask about Logseq DB schema, Datascript attributes, built-in classes, property types, entity relationships, schema validation, or the node/block/page data model. Provides authoritative knowledge of the DB graph architecture.
skill.summary: Deep expertise in Logseq's Datascript database schema. Auto-invokes when users ask about Logseq DB s...
skill.author: C0ntr0lledCha0s

security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based knowledge skill with read-only tools only. Contains documentation and templates for Logseq DB schema. No executable scripts, network calls, file writes, or code execution capabilities detected.

content.value_statement: Users struggle to understand Logseq's Datascript database architecture. This skill provides expert guidance on schema design, property types, class hierarchies, and entity relationships for effective knowledge graph management.
actual_capabilities: Explains Datascript attribute types and cardinality
Documents built-in class hierarchy with inheritance
Describes property type system and validators
Provides templates for custom properties and classes
Details Malli validation flow and schema versioning
Covers node model with page/block unified concept
limitations: Does not execute Datalog queries directly
Does not modify user graphs or databases
Does not provide real-time database access
Cannot create or update actual schema definitions

use_cases.title: Design custom property types
use_cases.description: Learn how to create typed properties with validation, closed values, and cardinality for structured data.

use_cases.title: Build Logseq plugins
use_cases.description: Understand schema architecture to develop plugins that work with Logsum's database model.

use_cases.title: Model complex relationships
use_cases.description: Design class hierarchies and entity relationships for sophisticated knowledge management.

prompt_templates.title: Schema basics
prompt_templates.prompt: Explain the basic structure of Logseq's Datascript database including attribute types and cardinality options.

prompt_templates.title: Property creation
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I create a custom property with closed values and cardinality settings?

prompt_templates.title: Class inheritance
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to create a custom class that extends another class with associated properties.

prompt_templates.title: Query patterns
prompt_templates.prompt: What are the common patterns for querying entities by class or property values in Logseq?

output_examples.input: What are the main built-in classes in Logseq?

best_practices: Start with Root class and extend through inheritance for proper class hierarchy.
Use appropriate property types (default, number, date, checkbox) based on data requirements.
Define closed values for properties with limited valid choices.
anti_patterns: Creating properties without specifying cardinality when multiple values are needed.
Extending wrong parent class causing unexpected behavior in queries.

faq.question: What versions of Logseq are supported?
faq.answer: This skill covers Logseq DB version 65.x and later with schema versioning support.

faq.question: Can this skill modify my Logseq database?
faq.answer: No. The skill only provides guidance. It cannot read or write to your actual graph files.

faq.question: What tools does this skill require?
faq.answer: Read, Grep, Glob, WebFetch, and WebSearch for accessing reference materials and documentation.

faq.question: Is my data safe with this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill is read-only and contains no code that accesses or modifies external data.

faq.question: How does this compare to other database skills?
faq.answer: This skill is Logsum-specific with deep knowledge of its unique Datascript schema and class system.

faq.question: Can I use this skill offline?
faq.answer: Core knowledge is contained in the skill. WebFetch/WebSearch require internet for external documentation.
